https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/76657/ : SUCCESS
Looks like there is a lot of formatting failures in CI.  Please make sure you're using our clang-format config.

This logic is a bit redundant.
If servName is equal to empty, the catch will be entered after calling the getDbusProperty method.
add a blank line and add comment
Do we need to consider service creation here?

matchParams did not need anymore.

The NameOwnerChanged needs to be optimized and submitted next time。

Do you need to filter sensor-related services?
Otherwise, I think as long as the service is removed, it will be executed here?
Please switch these to use sdbusplus::bus::callback_t instead of sd_bus_message_handle_t.  It will simplify these functions quite a bit.
Make these friend functions or static member functions of DbusSensor class.  That will simplify the class implementation.

Where did all of this come from??  Please use the phosphor-dbus-interfaces variant type directly rather than defining your own variant.

The way this is, you're assuming that all interfaces at a particular Sensor path can _only_ contain these types.  If any daemon comes along and adds a new interface at a path it is going to break all your processing.
Why are these public?  Why are they not returning auto?

Does this actually need a unique_ptr?

Should we combine this with signal also?

Why not std::array<match_t, 3>?
Based on the comments I've made, I really don't think it is safe to try to parse the property values out of the InterfacesAdded signal.  There is too much that can go wrong.
I don't really like the global typedef in the header that is only used in this one spot.  Just use a local typedef.
Since you're parsing this stuff out of an sdbus message without any try/catch, any change of property types by external daemons can end up causing your daemon to crash.  This isn't cool.

This is interface leakage.  There is no reason this code should know that NaN is a magic value and have to pass it along.

There are way too many places in this commit where you've introduced `quiet_NaN` as a magic value.
Huh?  Is there a sensorPath for a constant parameter??
Why are we keeping 2 instances of the value?
Why do we need the signalType here?  It seems like we're spreading a lot of information around in various functions.  I'll comment more on this later.

I don't know what this is doing.  Why don't we know this from the signal?

Why are we only matching one of the two?  I don't really know why this isn't using getParamServName + nameOwnerChanged or getParamPath + interfaceRemoved.
We can just have value be a default parameter to NaN.  Then the set will get NaN automatically, right?
Is this suppose to be an else?  I don't think so.  I don't really know what this line is doing.  We potentially cleared the sensor and now we're setting it to a potentially bogus value?
I don't see any place where nameOwnerChange is used.  Is there missing code?
Why do we have the value in the class *and* in DbusSensor?
There is absolutely no documentation on these parameters.  Please fix.
Add all this new boot progress stuff as a separate commit.  We need to handle multi-host designs.
Why are we resetting the nameOwnerChanged signal watch on every single sensor update?  I think you want to move this code inside the scope after line 62?

Change updateSensorValue  to initSensorValue 。

initSensorValue(Get SensorValue from DBUS call) will only be called during the first initialization or when a power on/off is detected. During initialization, calling may not obtain the serverName, so only when the serverName is not empty, listen for NameOwnerChange. So the calls won't be particularly frequent.

Prefer structured binding syntax:

```
auto [name, oldOwner, newOwner] = msg.unpack<std::string, std::string, std::string>();
```

What if newOwner is not empty?  Do we want to update name servName?

What if the service never comes back?

My intention is that during the transition from power on to power off, some sensor services will exit. At this time, I would like to clear the Value of the virtualSensor and not consider the scope of the remaining newOwners that are not empty. Perhaps this code may not be suitable, but I haven't found a better way to write it
Isn't this at least a warning?

Please use `"ERROR"` for all exceptions.

You don't need the `.what()` call.  lg2 handles this intrinsicly.
Is it a name or a path?  Seems strange to call it a NAME in the debug log.
Why are you creating a second reference to the message?  Just use `msg` directly.

How did you end up with these types?  I don't know how we end up with any property changed that isn't a `double` for `Sensor.Value`.

Please use `sdbusplus::server::xyz::openbmc_project::sensor::Value::PropertiesVariant`.  (I should move this to common...   https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/sdbusplus/+/67843 sdbus++: common: move PropertiesVariant from server)

In my project, there is listening to xyz.openbmc_project.State.Decorator.Availability and xyz.openbmc_project.State.Decorator.OperationalStatus， so bool has been added.

Currently, it will be removed. Add more later。
Same comments about logging as last handler.

Don't use static_cast for this.

`this->path == objPath` should work just fine.
Not reviewing.  New function in what is claimed to mostly be a refactoring commit.  Please separate.

namespace phosphor::virtual_sensor

- Style says Namespaces should be lower_snake_case.
- Prefer modern C++ nested namespaces rather than individual namespaces.
nit: I'd prefer to avoid using "context" or "ctx".  Async code tends to use context/ctx to mean something specific (the executing context of the async operation), which this isn't.
This isn't a ptr, which is just asking for confusion on the part of a code reader.  Style says not to use suffixes like this anyhow.

Why do we have boot progress code in phosphor-virtual-sensors?  Your implementation only supports single host, which isn't acceptable.

There is nothing in the existing code that deals with boot progress, as far as I can tell.  Please separate this into a separate commit.

Some sensors only create services after PowerON, and the service exits after PowerOFF. I only get the serviceName after Power On, so I hope to update the serviceName again after listening to Power On。

Okay, I will put it in the next submission。
Uh... is this left over from debug?
